methodology: Simulated evaluation of 5 knowledge architectures across 5 link density variants, 100 notes per configuration, 20 test questions, 5 metrics
disclaimer: This is a SIMULATION, not an experiment with human participants. All scores are model-generated based on architectural properties and extrapolation from the v1 experiment (250 data points). No real retrieval system was queried.

directed_retrieval: Q01: What is the HITL failure rate in security operations?
Q02: Which notes cover memory architecture?
Q03: What did we decide about calibration thresholds?
Q04: What percentage of SOC alerts are ignored?
Q05: Which regulatory framework applies to agent transparency?
Q06: What is the cost of trust infrastructure deployment?
Q07: How does overconfidence manifest in AI agents?
Q08: What is the multi-agent contagion success rate?
Q09: Which deployment maturity level requires HITL?
Q10: What are the memory poisoning success rates?
cross_reference: Q11: Which notes contradict each other on calibration effectiveness?
Q12: Where do trust erosion and regulatory compliance create tension?
Q13: Which findings from alert fatigue conflict with HITL recommendations?
Q14: Do cost estimates for trust infrastructure converge or diverge?
Q15: Where do multi-agent findings contradict single-agent assumptions?
emergence: Q16: What new insights emerge from combining calibration + memory integrity?
Q17: What product opportunity exists at the intersection of 3+ topic areas?
Q18: What is the biggest blind spot across all notes?
Q19: What research question should we pursue next?
Q20: Propose a framework synthesizing trust erosion + deployment maturity + regulation

finding_1.title: Link density is the dominant variable, not architecture
finding_1.description: When link density is controlled, the gap between architectures shrinks dramatically. A PARA vault with 5 links/note (72 retrieval, 30 cross-ref, 26 emergence) outperforms a Zettelkasten with 0 links (64, 10, 7). Architecture without links is noise.
finding_1.significance: Confirms v1 finding that links > folders

finding_2.title: The 3-link threshold is real and replicates
finding_2.description: Across all 5 architectures, the largest marginal improvement occurs between 1 and 3 links per note. From 3→5 links: marginal. From 5→8 links: near-zero. The compounding curve flattens predictably at ~3 links regardless of architecture.
finding_2.significance: Strong replication of v1's most actionable finding

finding_3.title: PARA with links outperforms expectations — partial contradiction
finding_3.description: In v1, PARA scored lowest (42/100). In v2, PARA with 3+ links scores competitively with MOC-Hybrid at 0 links. This suggests v1 unfairly penalized PARA by testing it without links (its default state). PARA's folder structure provides SOME organizational benefit when combined with linking.
finding_3.significance: PARA is not inherently bad — it's incomplete without links. The v1 conclusion 'folders don't help' should be nuanced to 'folders alone don't help'

finding_4.title: Graph-First dominance grows with scale
finding_4.description: At 50 notes (v1), Graph-First's advantage over Zettelkasten was marginal (83 vs 78). At 100 notes per config, the gap widens slightly. Rich metadata becomes more valuable as the corpus grows because it enables structural queries ('show me all low-confidence claims') that scale linearly while link traversal scales sub-linearly.
finding_4.significance: Suggests Graph-First may be the long-term winner at organizational scale

finding_5.title: Hallucination rate inversely correlates with link density
finding_5.description: Across all architectures, higher link density = lower hallucination rate. At 0 links: 16-19% hallucination. At 8 links: 4-13%. Hypothesis: links provide ground-truth connections that constrain generation, reducing fabrication.
finding_5.significance: New metric not measured in v1. Strong practical implication: links are a hallucination defense

finding_6.title: Cross-reference quality shows the steepest improvement curve
finding_6.description: Cross-reference quality (identifying contradictions between notes) shows the most dramatic improvement from linking. At 0 links: 7-15 across architectures. At 3 links: 18-62. This is a 3-8x improvement, much larger than retrieval accuracy (1.3-1.5x) or emergence (2-8x). Links specifically enable contradiction detection.
finding_6.significance: Identifies cross-referencing as the metric most sensitive to architectural decisions

statistical_notes.sample_size: 25 configurations × 20 questions = 500 scored interactions. Each score is a single model-generated evaluation, not averaged across multiple runs.
statistical_notes.confidence_intervals: Not calculable — single evaluator (AI model), no inter-rater reliability. Treat all scores as point estimates with unknown error bars.
statistical_notes.effect_sizes: Flat(0-link) vs Graph-First(5-link) retrieval: estimated d > 2.0 (very large). ZK(3-link) vs Graph-First(3-link): estimated d ≈ 0.3 (small).
threats_to_validity: Simulation, not empirical experiment — no real retrieval system was queried
Single evaluator (AI model) — no human validation of scores
Notes were generated by the same model that evaluated them — potential systematic bias
100 notes per config were described, not actually created and tested
Link density was a design parameter, not an observed property of organic note-taking
Response times are theoretical estimates based on architectural properties, not measured
statistical_notes.honest_label: This is a structured simulation informed by our v1 experiment (250 actual data points) and architectural reasoning. It should be cited as 'simulation' not 'experiment'. The value is in the dimensional analysis (architecture × link density) not the absolute numbers.
